answers.author: Mark Levin
answers.text:
This is not an unusual request as many newly elected officials' perceptions of their role and perks are based on big city and/or ficitional accounts. There are at least two approaches that the Manager might consider. The first is to educate the Mayor on the roles of the Manager and Mayor and the policies and past practices of the city. The second is to counsel the mayor that new staff and other perks have budgetary consequences, that any modifications to the budget will require the approval of the council and that before proceeding to direct the drafting of  legislation the Mayor should determine if a majority of the council will support these changes.
It is not uncommon for new Mayors, particularly in Council-Manager Cities, not to appreciate the role of the Council.

answers.author: Roderick Wood
answers.text:
A third approach, especially if you think the city council would not support this action,  is to advise the Mayor that current City Council Policy does not provide for separate staff and budgeting and you do not have the authority to change that policy as city manager.  However, you would be more then pleased to put the proposal together and place it on the Agenda for City council consideration.  In the end if the Council supports the plan, your stuck and it is after all their call.  On the Budget side you will need to show will need to be cut form the budget to fund this new program.
I would be certain to develop or update a formal City Council Policy Manual adopted by City Council Resolution to address this and all Council practices for future reference and to use the Policy Manual as the reason for your action so it is not the staff in the middle and the classic response form the affected elected "yea, but you would do it for so and so."

author: [Anonymous]
text:
Good Morning:
We have a new Mayor (NOT directly elected) and a fairly new City Manager.  This new Mayor has indicted he/she wants a full time staff office and other "perks" that normally are not provided to Council or Mayors in the past.  Does anyone have thoughts and ideas about how to manage this so that it does not become the City Manager's (and staff's) full time job to appease only the Mayor? 
Thanks!
title: Managing a New Mayor and Expectations
